doc.after: Since the 3rd edition, the Britannica has enjoyed a popular and critical reputation for general excellence.[2][3][5] The 3rd and the 9th editions were pirated for sale in the United States,[77] beginning with Dobson's Encyclopaedia.[78] On the release of the 14th edition, Time magazine dubbed the Britannica the "Patriarch of the Library".[79] In a related advertisement, naturalist William Beebe was quoted as saying that the Britannica was "beyond comparison because there is no competitor."[80] References to the Britannica can be found throughout English literature, most notably in one of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's favourite Sherlock Holmes stories, "The Red-Headed League". The tale was highlighted by the Lord Mayor of London, Gilbert Inglefield, at the bicentennial of the Britannica.[81]
